;中国一直是东南亚最大的发展伙伴和最大的官方发展资金来源，但根据洛伊研究所的一份新报告，中国面临着来自其他金融机构的日益激烈的竞争。

;

;基础设施资金占发展融资的大部分，但中国在这方面的贡献在 2020 年和 2021 年有所放缓，当时许多项目，包括那些在“一带一路”倡议中，没有实现，大流行减少了中国对东南亚的资助。

;

;2015 年至 2021 年期间，中国每年向东南亚支付约 50 亿美元的发展融资，基础设施建设约占 75%。基础设施通常包括运输和储存、能源、通信以及水和卫生设施方面的项目。

;

;报告称，在争夺影响力的地缘政治竞争中，向东南亚等地区提供援助的透明度越来越重要。

;

;“一带一路”计划在东南亚的“长期前景”面临风险：研究

;

;“中国与西方政府之间不断加剧的地缘战略紧张局势也导致人们越来越关注使用发展融资，特别是在基础设施，作为争夺影响力的一种手段，”洛伊研究所印度洋-太平洋发展中心主任罗兰·拉贾 (Roland Rajah) 说。

;

;“这使得了解东南亚官方发展融资的规模和轮廓变得至关重要给该地区的政府及其发展伙伴。”

;

;尽管东南亚经济不断进步，但该地区仍然“面临大量未满足的融资需求，特别是在基础设施、人类发展和应对气候变化”，报告说。

;

;“这意味着由各种形式的官方发展资金——赠款、贷款和其他形式的援助——资助的发展合作可以发挥关键作用。”< /p>;

;以印度尼西亚为例，其经济价值 1.3 万亿美元，是该地区最大的经济体，来自其他国家的发展融资贡献仍占政府总支出的 10% 以上。

;

;即使是马来西亚和泰国等较富裕的东南亚国家也获得了大量的发展资金援助，尤其是来自中国的资金援助。

;

;与日本、欧洲和韩国等传统发展伙伴不同，中国已经资助了一些国家报告称，马来西亚和泰国分别拥有东海岸铁路项目和泰中高速铁路项目等项目，尽管它们是“该地区高收入国家”。

;

;其他接受中国发展援助的国家是其邻国老挝和柬埔寨。

;

;“随着中国实力的增长，北京一直主张重组全球治理体系，以更好地符合其利益和价值观， ”洛伊报告说。

;

;“作为这项努力的一部分，中国发起了多项大规模倡议，例如“一带一路”倡议……其目的是将中国定位为全球公共产品的提供者，通过提供中国资源和解决方案来应对发展挑战。”

;

;继中国之后，亚洲开发银行和世界银行等传统多边金融机构是该地区第二和第三大发展融资提供者，正在与中国竞争成为该地区的首选融资方。

;

;中国在基础设施开发融资方面还面临来自日本、韩国和欧洲的竞争，而美国和澳大利亚在这方面的竞争规模较小

;

;报告称，虽然中国的签约额超过了传统捐助方，但这些传统合作伙伴通常在实际交付方面做得更好。

;

;继中国之后，伊斯兰开发银行是该地区下一个最具影响力的非传统发展金融机构，每年向该地区提供约 2.25 亿美元。

;

;其中大部分以非优惠贷款的形式流向印度尼西亚，重点是农业和教育。

;

;沙特阿拉伯正在成为该地区最大的双边中东发展伙伴，每年提供约 4500 万美元，主要用于奖学金。

;

;印度也是一个非传统援助提供者，缅甸也是一个正在崛起的双边合作伙伴，每年向该地区提供约 7000 万美元的发展融资。

;

;缅甸获得了这笔资金的近 90%，用于交通和能源项目。

;

;东南部报告称，在审查过程中，亚洲可能因一带一路债务而“感受到压力”

;

;在该地区，在提供发展融资援助方面，并非最富有的国家承担了重任。< /p>;

;“柬埔寨和东帝汶是东南亚最贫穷的经济体之一……从提供的发展资金与收到的资金的比率来看，东帝汶是第二大慷慨的东南亚合作伙伴，而柬埔寨是第四，”报告称。

;

;柬埔寨向该地区提供人道主义支持，而东帝汶则向其东盟邻国提供紧急援助。

;

;东南亚两个富裕国家新加坡和文莱，报告称，表现不佳，仅贡献了区域内发展资金的 2.6%。

;印度不会对中国构成安全威胁，因为它仍然无法挑战北京出席亚洲首屈一指的安全论坛的中国军方代表表示，中国在国防制造和军队现代化方面的进展。

;

;在周日闭幕的新加坡香格里拉对话期间，中国人民解放军向媒体发表讲话(PLA) 代表表示，印度要赶上中国的军队还有很长的路要走，尤其是在国防工业方面。

;

;“由于工业基础设施薄弱，印度不太可能在未来几十年内赶上中国，而中国已经建立了复杂而系统的国防工业平台，”中国人民解放军军事科学院赵小卓大校说。

;

;“当你看看印度军队的武器系统时，什么类型的坦克，飞机军舰是印度自己制造和开发的？”

;

;香格里拉对话：中美安全愿景的竞争

;

;2018 年至 2022 年，印度是世界上最大的主要武器进口国，根据斯德哥尔摩国际和平研究所的数据，该时期其武器总量的 31% 来自俄罗斯。

;

;其他国家已经做到了，”中国人民解放军国防大学副教授、代表团成员张驰大校说。

;

;不过，赵说印度军队的现代化及其在美国的作用-领导的四方安全对话——一个非正式联盟，更广为人知的是“四方联盟”，其中还包括日本和澳大利亚，旨在对抗崛起的中国——不会影响北京和新德里在金砖国家和上海合作组织等多边平台上的合作组织 (SCO)。

;

;BRICS 是由巴西、俄罗斯、印度、中国和南非组成的主要新兴市场集团的首字母缩写，而 SCO 是由北京领导的专注于区域安全的组织，包括打击恐怖主义、分裂主义和极端主义。

;

;中国和印度在喜马拉雅山的边界沿线对峙，2020 年发生了一场致命冲突，导致 20 名印度士兵和 4 名解放军士兵丧生。

;

;赵说北京认为印度不会因为其独立的外交政策而成为美国印太战略的“忠实伙伴”。

;

;张说印度是不结盟运动的早期倡导者（ NAM），它与中国国家主席习近平的新安全倡议有共同点。

;

;NAM 成立于冷战期间，是一个国家集团，主要位于全球南方，没有正式结盟大国和反对殖民主义、帝国主义和外国干涉的国家。

;

;然而，前印度驻丹麦大使、印中关系专家 Yogesh Gupta 不同意，他说 NAM 与新德里在

;

;“当中国对印度采取侵略和霸权姿态时，印度没有义务遵循 [the] NAM 的理想，”他说，指的是

;

;“如果中国不愿意在双边层面的会谈中纠正错误态度，两国将如何改善上合组织和金砖国家的关系？由于北京的立场顽固，这些团体没有取得太大进展。”

;

;解放军代表团表示，中国及其亚洲邻国更愿意通过对话、交流和谈判——“亚洲模式”——来解决他们的问题。领土争端。

;

;香格里拉对话：美国和中国在台湾、南中国海问题上站稳脚跟

;

;作为世界上最大的军队，拥有 200 万兵力的解放军设定了一个目标到 2027 年，也就是建军一百周年，成为一支现代化的战斗力量，这促使美国和许多国防智库建议北京可能最早在当年攻打台湾。

;

;曹延忠大校，研究员中国人民解放军军事科学院驳斥了这种猜测，称 2027 年的最后期限只是中国军队现代化努力的一部分，其其他目标包括到 2035 年建设蓝水海军，并拥有与中国相当的一流军队。美国到 2049 年。

;

;曹说，谈到台湾，华盛顿的“威慑战略”无法阻止解放军缩减其在自治岛屿周围的飞机和军舰部署，演习是目的是向台湾和其他地方的支持独立的势力施加压力，以免将台湾从中国分裂出去。

;被监禁的反对派领袖阿列克谢·纳瓦尔尼在他的支持者举行的会议上表达了对俄罗斯更美好未来的希望纠察队和示威活动将在周日纪念他的 47 岁生日。

;

;纳瓦尔尼因欺诈和藐视法庭罪被判 9 年徒刑，他说这些指控是编造出来的，目的是惩罚他揭露官员腐败和组织反克里姆林宫抗议活动。

;

;他正面临一项关于极端主义指控的新审判，这可能会使他在监狱中待上数十年。克里姆林宫的批评者认为此案是俄罗斯政府又一次试图孤立弗拉基米尔·普京总统最主要的敌人。

;

;助手说，俄罗斯的纳瓦尔尼生病，可能再次被毒死

;

;纳瓦尔尼的同伙呼吁示威周日在俄罗斯和国外表达对他的支持。

;

;俄罗斯的一些纳瓦尔尼支持者冒着自己被判入狱的风险，举着单独的纠察线庆祝他的生日，而其他人则涂鸦。警方迅速拘留了许多人接受讯问，并在莫斯科市中心加强了警力。

;

;欧洲多个城市举行了支持纳瓦尔尼的示威活动。

;

;纳瓦尔尼在社交媒体上说他的盟友发布的帖子说，他显然更愿意与家人一起吃早餐、孩子们的亲吻和礼物来度过他的生日，但“生活就是这样，只有一定数量的人愿意，才能实现社会进步和更美好的未来。为拥有信仰的权利付出代价。

;

;“这样的人越多，每个人要付出的代价就越小，”他说。 “总有一天，在俄罗斯讲真话和维护正义将成为例行公事，一点也不危险。”

;

;纳瓦尔尼在莫斯科休养后于 2021 年 1 月返回莫斯科时被捕。德国因神经毒剂中毒而死，他将此归咎于克里姆林宫。

;

;他最初因违反假释规定被判处 2.5 年徒刑。去年，他因欺诈和藐视法庭罪被判处九年徒刑。他目前在莫斯科以东 250 公里（150 英里）的最高戒备监狱服刑。

;

;对纳瓦尔尼的极端主义指控可能会让他在监狱服刑 30 年，这与他的活动有关反腐败基金会和他的高级同事的声明。他的盟友表示，这些指控追溯性地将纳瓦尔尼基金会自 2011 年成立以来的所有活动定为刑事犯罪。

;

;新的指控出台之际，俄罗斯当局正在加强对乌克兰战斗中持不同政见者的镇压，纳瓦尔尼对乌克兰的战斗持严厉态度

;

;莫斯科一家法院定于周二举行初步听证会，讨论与对纳瓦尔尼的新审判有关的技术问题，拒绝了他的律师要求有更多时间审查大量新指控的请求，他拒绝称这些指控“荒谬” ”。

;

;纳瓦尔尼还援引一名调查人员的话说，他还将因恐怖主义指控面临单独的军事法庭审判，可能会被判无期徒刑。

;

;他在社交媒体上说周日发帖说，他认为自己的刑期“只是我最喜欢的工作中令人不愉快的一部分”，并感谢他的支持者。

;

;“我去年的计划是不要变得残酷和怨恨，也不要失去行为的冷漠——这就是失败的开始，”他写道。 “如果我成功了，那要感谢你们的支持。”

; Sun, 04 Jun 2023 21:20:02 +0800 As China’s local governments struggle to repay debts, should Beijing shoulder some of the burden?https://www.scmp.com/economy/china-economy/article/3222441/chinas-local-governments-struggle-repay-debts-should-beijing-shoulder-some-burden?utm_source=rss_feed

;中国地方政府债务危机正接近临界点，对市县政府的担忧违约风险上升，北京提供足够支持以避免崩溃的意愿受到质疑。

;

;上个月底，西南省份云南省省会昆明否认了网上关于其地方政府融资平台 (LGFV) 的报道5 月 21 日，其中一家在最后一刻争相偿还 20 亿元人民币（2.823 亿美元），导致难以偿还债务。

;

;LGFV 的创建是为了帮助预算外融资，尤其是对于基础设施支出，但薄弱的披露要求引发了对隐性债务风险的担忧。

;

;4 月，贵州政府智库警告称，与云南相邻的贵州无法自行管理债务，需要中央政府的帮助。该报告随后被审查员删除。

;

;在过去几年中，北京加强了对地方政府债务的监管以遏制风险，并表示地方政府不应指望国家救助.

;

;但著名经济学家、前央行顾问余永定表示，中央政府依靠地方政府解决债务问题的做法是错误的。

;

;“地方政府是中央政府的后代，中央政府也必须承担一定的责任，”于 5 月 4 日在中国智库经济学家 50 人论坛发表的一篇博文中写道。

;

;“重要的是，解决地方政府债务不应导致经济增长进一步下滑。当然，不能鼓励道德风险。造成地方债务恶化的直接责任人也应承担相应的责任。”

;

;中国警告缩小城乡差距存在“大”债务风险

;

;于据估计，中央政府仅贡献了约 0.1% 的基础设施支出，而地方政府融资平台贡献了近 60%，这导致借贷成本更高。

;

;美国联邦储备银行前高级经济学家胡杰亚特兰大教授、现为上海交通大学教授的他表示，许多省份的地方债务占国内生产总值 (GDP) 的比例已经“过高”。

;

;去杠杆“过快”可能引发胡锦涛在上月底发表的一次采访中告诉上海新闻网站 guancha.cn。

;

;中央政府不能置身事外，”胡说。

;

;地方政府的表外借款没有官方数据，但大多数估计表明它一直在增长。

;

;北京警告称在提振经济的过程中需要将中国的债务风险降至最低

;

;国际货币基金组织在 2 月份发布的一份报告中估计，今年中国地方政府融资平台的债务总额已增至创纪录的 66 万亿元人民币， 2017 年增加了一倍多，达到 30.7 万亿元人民币。

;

;法国投资银行 Natixis 的另一项估计显示，2022 年最后一个季度中国的公共债务占 GDP 的 95%，低于美国的 120% 和欧元区的 92%。

;

;但 Natixis 承认其估计存在局限性，因为它们依赖于公开披露，而且一些数据不易获得。

;

;中国重新开始的基础设施支出推动支持经济引发了对地方政府债务可持续性的质疑。

;

;许多地方政府的财政收入大幅下降，房地产市场低迷，再融资成本上升。

;

;上周，位于中国中部湖北省省会武汉市的财政局在当地报纸的一篇文章中公开点名要求偿还可追溯至 2018 年 12 月的数百名债务人，这一罕见举措突显了地方政府面临的财政问题。

;

;Li清华大学中国经济实践与思想学术中心主任、中国人民银行前顾问稻葵表示，中央政府应该接管地方政府的部分债务负担。

;

;“完全依靠地方财政和地方国企的利润连还本付息的成本都不够，更别提还本付息了。这是不可持续的，”李在上个月大学安排的一个论坛上说。

;

;“我们研究所建议，未来发债必须经过一定的程序。同时，相当一部分地方债务应该转移给中央政府。”

;

;分析人士表示，如果中国的债务危机没有长期解决方案，投资者的信心将受到打击。

;

;民生证券上月底表示，自年初以来，昆明大部分地方政府融资平台已经失去了资本市场，主要依靠地方政府的资金。

;

;“也许市场认为最终还款的可能性仍然很高，但这个过程中的这些小问题将进一步增加区域压力，可能变成一个负循环，”它说。

;

;“未来，如果想要恢复资本市场的认可，再次在市场上出售债券，难度可想而知。”

; Sun, 04 Jun 2023 18:20:02 +0800 Shangri-La Dialogue: China and the US offer competing security visions for the Asia-Pacifichttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/military/article/3222906/shangri-la-dialogue-china-and-us-offer-competing-security-visions-asia-pacific?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.04 18:16;
;;

;China's new defence minister used his first public address to an international audience to lash out at the US and the “rules-based international order” it champions, as well as call for common ground to avoid the “unbearable pain” a conflict between them would bring.

;

;At the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore on Sunday, General Li Shangfu accused “some countries” of intervening in another's internal affairs and pursuing its security at the expense of others.

;

;“Some countries intervene in the internal and regional affairs of other countries, frequently impose unilateral sanctions, threaten to use force, launch colour revolutions and proxy wars everywhere,” Li said to hundreds of defence analysts, officials and academics at Asia's biggest security conference.

;

;“They then leave after bringing chaos to a region, leaving behind a mess. We must not allow this to be replicated in the Asia-Pacific.”

;

;The speech came on the last day of the conference where military officials from around the world held more than a hundred formal closed-door meetings.

;

;But as expected, there was not one between Li and his US counterpart, Lloyd Austin. Li had turned down an offer for talks because of secondary US sanctions over arms purchases from Russia.

;

;Shangri-La Dialogue puts focus on shifting US-China military balance

;

;In the main conference room, Li laid out Chinese President Xi Jinping's signature Global Security Initiative, a foreign policy strategy based on economic development.

;

;Like Austin a day earlier, the Chinese defence minister tackled some of the big points of friction between the two countries: Taiwan and the South China Sea.

;

;However, there was little overlap in the two visions presented.

;

;Li said “Taiwan is China's Taiwan” and “a matter for the Chinese to decide”, while Austin said the United States would oppose unilateral changes to the status quo from either side.

;

;Without naming the US, Li also accused “some country” of exceptionalism and double standards.

;

;“Its so-called rules-based international order never tells you what the rules are, and who made these rules,” he said.

;

;“Some countries even use treaties that it is not party to, to restrict others.”

;

;One of those treaties is the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, or Unclos. The US has not signed the convention but it recognises the obligations in it as binding customary international law.

;

;The rules of the sea were in sharp focus on the weekend when the US Indo-Pacific Command said a Chinese destroyer overtook and crossed the path of the USS Chung-Hoon at 137 metres (150 yards) in an unsafe way in the Taiwan Strait.

;

;Asked about the encounter, Li said: “What is key now is that we must prevent attempts to use freedom of navigation … as a pretext to exercise hegemony of navigation.”

;

;At the time, the US destroyer was sailing with the Canadian frigate HMCS Montreal, cooperation that the US Seventh Fleet said reflected the US approach to a secure and prosperous region.

;

;What message does China defence chief have for Shangri-La Dialogue?

;

;In his speech, Li took aim at such US-led alliances in the Asia-Pacific.

;

;He accused Nato of dividing Asia by expanding. Other PLA officers cited Japan's plans to open a Nato liaison office and South Korea's joining of a Nato cyber defence centre. Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida, however, has already ruled out Japan joining the collective defence alliance.

;

;“The crux of attempts at 'Nato-fication' of the Asia-Pacific is to hold regional nations hostage, promote conflict and confrontation, and plunge the Asia-Pacific into a whirlpool of division, disputes and conflicts,” he said.

;

;“Bloc politics” – often how Beijing describes US alliance-building – would destabilise the region, he said.

;

;While Li acknowledged a stark difference between the US and Chinese political systems, he said it should not stop the two countries from cooperating on matters of common interests.

;

;“We in China believe that the key for countries to live in harmony is mutual respect and treating each other as equals,” he said.

;

;“We are strongly opposed to imposing one's own will on others, placing one's own interests above those of others and pursuing one's own security at the expense of others.”

;

;Why the US and Chinese defence ministers should meet at the Shangri-La Dialogue

;

;On the sidelines of the conference, Senior Colonel Cao Yanzhong, research fellow with the PLA Academy of Military Sciences, said the “US deterrence strategy” could not deter the People's Liberation Army from scaling down its deployment of aircraft and warships to drill around Taiwan.

;

;However, that did not suggest the PLA would attack the island in 2027, the PLA's centenary, he said. Beijing has described the 2027 milestone as a stage of military modernisation. Some US military officials have regarded 2027 as a year of a potential attack.

;

;Drew Thompson, a visiting senior research fellow with the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy in Singapore, said Li's speech showed China's words did not match its deeds.

;

;“A big takeaway from that encounter was that the region believes that China's actions do not match its rhetoric. China is saying the right things, but it's not doing the right things,” he said.

;

;Thompson, who was also the director for China, Taiwan and Mongolia in the US defence secretary's office from 2011 to 2018, said two intercepts by Chinese forces had occurred in one week, events that were inconsistent with the memorandums of understanding between China and the US governing air and sea encounters.

;

;“So, the question in the minds of everyone in the room is under what conditions will China live up to international rules and agreements that it has signed? Or why it doesn't follow the rules that it has agreed to?”

;China's grain security could be tested this summer, as several ministries have warned that extreme weather, including droughts and floods, might plague agricultural areas in the coming months.

;

;The warning from China's emergency management ministry came as the central province of Henan has possibly lost more than 20 million tonnes of wheat this spring because of longer-than-expected rainfall before the harvest, while crops in the southwestern province of Yunnan have been hit hard by persistent droughts.

;

;An analysis, published on the ministry's website on Friday, predicted that northeastern and northern China, home to some of the country's top grain-producing provinces, might experience heavy rain, floods and hailstorms from June to August.

;

;The National Disaster Reduction Committee Office and ministries of natural resources, water resources, agriculture and rural affairs as well as the China Meteorological Administration and State Forestry and Grassland Administration also contributed to the analysis.

;

;China's wheat crops face 'unprecedented' risks as the world heats up

;

;According to the report, there is a significant risk of flooding in the middle and lower reaches of the Yellow River, the Songliao River, the Songhua River and the Heilongjiang River, among others.

;

;These areas include Henan, China's largest wheat-growing province, as well as the northeastern Heilongjiang province, known as China's “grain barn”, along with other major grain producers.

;

;While the north may face a heightened risk of water-related disasters, the south is highly likely to face drought, according to the government analysis.

;

;Southwest China's Chongqing municipality and Sichuan province, both major aluminium suppliers and home to renewable energy facilities, may experience a 20 to 50 per cent reduction in rainfall, heightening the risk of summer drought.

;

;Meanwhile eastern China, which serves as a key engine of economic growth, may experience typhoon-related disasters as the storms make landfall earlier than usual this year.

;

;Facing climate change, supply-chain upheavals and external uncertainties, including the Ukraine war, Beijing has repeatedly declared food security an urgent priority, with President Xi Jinping calling agriculture a “national security issue of extreme importance”.

;

;In recent years, Chinese authorities have stepped up efforts to ensure the country has enough food to feed its 1.4 billion people. However, a spate of extreme spring weather and the latest prediction might hamper China's efforts to safeguard its food security and compound concerns about the country's economic recovery.

;

;A total of 184 national meteorological stations across China recorded extreme events from March to May, with temperatures at 77 stations hitting or breaking historical records in the same period, according to another report published by China's national climate centre.

;

;'Harvest wheat ASAP': Beijing urges all-out efforts to limit rain-damage fallout

;

;China's average temperatures were higher than usual from March to May, ranking seventh highest on record, while overall rainfall reached its lowest level since 2012 during the period, the climate centre said.

;

;The extreme weather varied between regions, with southern and southwestern China experiencing below-average rainfall in the spring, while northern and central China experienced above-average rainfall.

;

;Yunnan province in the southwest faced a severe winter and spring drought, which negatively affected the growth of spring crops. The province is China's second-largest source of hydropower, with 80 per cent of its local power supply coming from hydropower, but the drought caused a shortfall in electricity generation because of low water inflows.

;

;Ella Irwin, Twitter's head of trust and safety, confirmed her resignation in a pair of tweets late Friday. ;

;Musk was responding to complaints by Jeremy Boreing, co-CEO of the media company, the Daily Wire. ;Irwin tweeted Friday that “one or two people noticed” she left the company the day before, and she noted speculation about whether she was fired or quit. She teased that she would post 24 tweets to explain her departure.

;Next to Musk, Irwin had been the most prominent voice of the company's ever-changing content policies in recent months.

;Singapore's Ng on Sunday stressed that the US-China relationship was “central” to the stability in Asia and the broader Indo-Pacific region. “No country, I think, wants war but our working assumptions and scenarios must be that unplanned incidents can occur,” he said.

;

;He cited a 2001 incident where a US spy plane and a Chinese aircraft collided near Hainan Island. More recently, there have been close encounters between American and Chinese naval vessels and fighter jets in the South China Sea and the Taiwan Strait.

;

;“Channels of communication, both formal and informal, must exist so that when these unplanned incidents occur, those channels can be used to de-escalate and avoid conflict,” Ng said, adding that it would be “too late” to start or activate these channels in moments of crisis.

;

;For leaders in Asia, the “foremost priority” would be to avoid a physical conflict in the region and to draw lessons from the Ukraine war. Simultaneous conflicts in Europe and Asia would be “disastrous” and a “nightmarish scenario”, he said.

;

;Ng added that there were currently “declining touch points” between Beijing and Washington. Singapore, and more broadly, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean), is not “disinterested bystanders”.

;

;Shangri-La Dialogue: US and China stand ground on Taiwan, South China Sea

;

;“Both the US and China have said that they do not want our countries – Asean countries – to take sides,” he said.

;

;“But Asean member states with a vivid recollection of great power rivalry in our past and the devastating consequences are acutely concerned that worsening relationships between these two powers … will inevitably force difficult choices upon our individual states.”

;

;Ng suggested that an earlier established hotline between US and China militaries would make a “crucial difference in the de-escalation of hostilities” in the event of an unplanned incident.

;

;Southeast Asian leaders have firmly maintained that they would not take sides amid the worsening US-China strategic rivalry as many of them depended on China for trade and have deep security ties with the US.

;

;Cambodian Defence Minister Tea Banh, who was on the same panel as Ng, said tensions between major powers have “hindered the harmonisation and prosperity” of other nations.

;

;“It was obvious that competing parties will not gain any substantial benefit [from heightened competition]. It is inevitable that they remain dependent on one another for the long term,” said Banh, who is also deputy prime minister.

;

;He said Cambodia does not want to see either China or the US decline because it would pose risks to the region and the world.

;

;Shangri-La Dialogue puts focus on shifting US-China military balance

;

;“Cambodia wishes to see changes in the practice of rival nations from tit-for-tat to working together to achieve shared benefit, stability and prosperity for the region and the world,” he added.

;

;Analysts previously suggested that Southeast Asia's defence leaders would seek to air their concerns over spiralling US-China ties when they meet their American and Chinese counterparts at this week's Shangri-La Dialogue.

;

;On Saturday, Philippines Defence Secretary Carlito Galvez Jnr expressed concern over the great power rivalry spilling over to the South China Sea.

;

;China claims almost the entire resource-rich waterway and while the US is not a claimant state, it regularly conducts freedom of navigation operations in those waters.

;

;Galvez said Manila – which has encountered run-ins with Chinese vessels in recent months – hoped “relevant parties … will find useful and effective ways to manage their divergent positions without prejudice to their respective legitimate practice”.

;

;“As the old adage goes, good fences make good neighbours, as it is only when neighbours have clear boundaries and respect for set boundaries will the relationship be genuinely amicable,” he said.

;

;“The declining state of goodwill in the region will only serve the return of the iron curtain that will undermine any potential for confidence building and cooperation between and among us.”
